{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3523158,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-11T08:27:34.250Z","cooked":"

There are so many threads complaining about CAN Bus problems. Sometimes, failure on the CAN Bus can cost a match. I want to create a thread for all the tips and troubleshooting guides on the CAN Bus. Your contributions are more than appreciated. Any suggestions and corrections can be posted below, and I will add them later.

(edit: ChatGPT grammar fix)

There are two types of CAN Bus on FRC robot.

Image: two types of CAN Bus

Source: https://store.ctr-electronics.com/products/canivore1280√ó1208 162 KB

  1. roboRIO CAN Bus (the one where Talon SRX controllers are connected) - Built-in port on the roboRIO. Pretty much all FRC-legal CAN devices can be connected to this bus.
  2. CANivore CAN Bus (the one where Falcon motors are connected) - USB extended from CANivore. Only CTRE CAN FD devices can be connected to this bus.

These two CAN Buses CANNOT be interconnected. They must be isolated from each other. This means CANivore cannot exist on the roboRIO CAN Bus and vice versa.

There are several ways to wire CAN a Bus.

Image: CAN twisted pair cable

A CAN Bus connection should be made using at least 22 AWG (0.5 mm¬≤) twisted pair cable, color-coded in Yellow/Green. This is because CAN Bus is a differential signal, and twisted pair cable ensures that electromagnetic interference affects the signal in both wires uniformly, limiting errors. (Source)

Image: start and chain Bus

Source: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/can-bus-in-parallel-or-series/468548/121364√ó765 24.9 KB

(Thanks for @andej 's suggestion for the edit)

When it comes to connecting devices on the Bus, the most common way is a chain Bus. In this topology, one device will connect after each other in a daisy chain. At both end of the chain, a termination is needed. This is the most recommended way when it comes to topology.

Sometimes on rare occasion a star (branched) Bus might be necessary. However, this is not really the recommended way to do CAN Bus. In the past with CAN 2.0, teams with very short CAN buses may have been able to get some degree of success without ensuring the above requirements are met, such as with star or ring topologies. However, as transmission frequencies increase (such as in CAN FD), it is more important to ensure proper bus topology (daisy chain or short stub lengths). (Source & @andej ) please avoid this kind of network at all cost unless you have no option (for example, a mechanism was slippering that cannot accommodate 4 conductor for CAN Bus).

When making a star Bus, make sure to insulate the unconnected leads. If using Krakens with bolted connections, you can make cables with only one lead. (Source @Mike_Schreiber ) You don‚Äôt need to terminate every single device in a star Bus stop (except for the last one at a distinct end).

Image: termination on both end of CAN Bus

The CAN Bus is bidirectional, and both ends of the cable must be terminated. However, only the two nodes at the far ends of the cable, not every node on the bus, require termination resistors. (Source) Termination is done using a 120 Ohm resistor at both distinct ends of the CAN Bus. Not doing so could cause CAN Bus instability or complete failure. (Source)

There are several ways to terminate the CAN Bus on an FRC Robot.

On roboRIO CAN Bus:

  • The roboRIO has a built-in termination resistor. As the roboRIO is always the first device in this CAN Bus, nothing is needed at this end.

  • All power distribution devices (PDP / PDH) have a jumper that enables the termination resistor. If these devices are used as termination, they should be placed as the last device on the Bus. It is strongly recommended that you connect your power distribution device onto the CAN Bus for current logging if your device supports it (all PD devices except CTRE PDP 2.0 have this feature). Even though this is no longer required in 2025, current logging makes troubleshooting for brownouts much easier.

Images: termination jumpers on power distribution device

For CTRE PDP, a jumper could be set to enable termination resistor.

Source: https://ctre.download/files/user-manual/PDP%20User's%20Guide.pdf1318√ó736 73.1 KB

For REV PDH, a switch label ‚ÄúTERM‚Äù could be flipped to enable termination resistor.
Source: https://docs.revrobotics.com/ion-control-system/pdh/overview1192√ó728 54.7 KB

  • Certain third-party devices, such as Swyft Cannect, have built-in termination resistors. Refer to the manufacturer‚Äôs recommendation when using these devices to ensure the proper termination of your CAN Bus.
  • A 120 Ohm resistor can be manually added at the end of the CAN Bus.

On CANivore CAN Bus

  • The CANivore has a 120 Ohm programmable resistor for terminating the CAN Bus. The resistor can be configured using the CAN Bus Termination toggle in the CANivore device card in Phoenix Tuner X. (Source) You need to open Phoenix Tuner X and manually enable this option.
Image: Phoenix Tuner X CAN Bus Termination toggle

Source: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/2024/docs/canivore/canivore-config.html1054√ó767 26.6 KB

  • A 120 Ohm resistor must be manually added at the end of the CAN Bus. All power distribution devices do not support CAN FD, which means they can only be connected to the roboRIO CAN Bus. Unless you have a third-party device that supports CAN FD termination, you will need to add this resistor manually.
  • Certain third-party devices, such as Swyft Cannect, have built-in termination resistors. Refer to the manufacturer‚Äôs recommendation when using these devices to ensure proper termination of your CAN Bus.

Vendor library are needed

Due to the complexity of CAN devices, most peripherals require third-party libraries in your code to function properly. Each device from a different vendor will have a unique set of APIs. Always refer to the latest documentation from each vendor.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Third-Party CAN Devices

A number of FRC ¬Æ vendors offer their own CAN peripherals. As CAN devices offer expansive feature-sets, vendor CAN devices require similarly expansive code libraries to operate. As a result, these ...

Each vendor provides configuration software for their CAN devices. Here are some major ones:

  • CTRE: Phoenix Tuner X
  • REV Robotics: REV Hardware Client
  • Redux Robotics: Alchemist
  • Grapple Robotics: GrappleHook
  • The Thrifty Bot: Thrifty Config Software

If you use a CAN device from a vendor, you must install the appropriate configuration software on your computer to set the ID and update the firmware for your CAN device. Firmware and software across different companies are not interchangeable. The firmware version must match the library in your robot code. A mismatch could cause degraded performance, high bus utilization, and software bugs.

Each CAN device needs a unique ID. If two devices from the same manufacturer on the same bus have the same ID, both devices will not function correctly. Usually, two devices from different manufacturers can have the same ID; however, it is strongly not recommended to do this to avoid confusion. A device will have an ID of 0 if it is new, has its firmware updated, or has been factory reset. You must change the ID from 0, or your device won‚Äôt work properly. Please refer to the documentation from your device manufacturer on how to set the ID, as each device is slightly different.

Troubleshooting tips

These are some of the most common issues when it comes to CAN Bus failures.

Wiring Issues

To troubleshoot these kinds of issues, a digital multimeter can be used to test continuity between wires. When doing so, make sure the battery is disconnected. Test continuity between both CAN Bus wires, between each CAN Bus wire and multiple points on the robot frame, and between each CAN Bus wire and battery positive/ground. There should not be any continuity.

  • Wires that are shorted together, touching the robot frame, or other non-CAN Bus wires.
  • Loose connectors, crimps, etc.

Termination Issues

Use a digital multimeter to measure resistance between CAN Bus wires. When doing so, make sure the battery is disconnected. If the resistance is near 60-120 Ohms, your termination should be good. If the measurement turns out to be several kiloohms, you need to check your termination.

  • Missing termination resistor (very common for CANivore CAN Bus).
  • Jumper in the wrong position.
  • Switch in the wrong position.
  • Damaged wire or solder point to the termination resistor.
  • Disconnected device.

Device Issues

Sometimes a broken device could send rogue packets onto the Bus. This can also be caused by old or corrupted firmware. When this happens, it is critical to isolate the device causing the issue. You might need to disconnect CAN devices from the Bus one by one until the problem disappears. Then, reconnect only that device back to the roboRIO or CANivore and see if the problem reappears.

Non-CAN FD Device on CAN FD Bus

Only certain devices supporting CAN FD from CTRE should be connected with CANivore. The CANivore Bus should not be connected with the roboRIO Bus.

High Utilization

Too many devices on the same Bus can cause issues. Ideally, an average of less than 80% utilization is desired. You can check Bus utilization on Driver Station and Phoenix Tuner X. Sometimes, a firmware update could reduce utilization. However, if you simply have too many devices, you might consider moving some devices to another bus. Currently, only CTRE supports this with CANivore, and only CTRE CAN FD devices can be connected to this bus.

Code Issues

There could be multiple reasons behind these kinds of problems, and they are often the most frustrating to troubleshoot. Sometimes, it is the vendor‚Äôs library causing the issue, while other times, it could be your code pulling data from the device too frequently. This might be one of those moments when you need to contact manufacturer support, make a post on Chief Delphi, and spend a lot of time debugging. However, it is critical to isolate the issue from the other types of failures. Consider loading a basic code where you have all your CAN devices initialized but performing no actions to confirm that it is not a communication problem.

This seems generally fine, however, I‚Äôm very concerned by your recommendation/endorsement of star canbus topology without any discussion of stub lengths.

While you can more or less get away with it on 2.0B (see: ti appnote‚Äôs guideline of 1/3 the total bus length*), CTRE‚Äôs FD data rates are 10x 2.0B rates**, so you can‚Äôt play as fast and loose with it anymore.

CTRE themselves in the CANivore user‚Äôs guide (page 21) strongly caution against star topologies, and anything with a branch longer than 12 inches is not considered reliable.

I think star topologies are especially likely to cause issues and hellish to debug, because their issues (impedance mismatches and signal reflections) are somewhat abstract and hard to reason about, they require a proper oscilloscope to fully identify (as opposed to a multimeter resistance or continuity check), and they don‚Äôt really make it obvious what‚Äôs wrong (e.g. the canbus just suddenly develops very high utilization).

Anyway, decent write up, and I‚Äôd be happy to contribute if you‚Äôd like (in the form of some content that I think should be more emphasized, and rewrite passes to clean up some of the LLM residue).

* the ISO 11898 standard (as cited by TI because the actual standard is closed) limits unterminated stub length to 30cm as well, but the TI note acknowledges that since 2.0B doesn‚Äôt have particularly fast signalling you can get away with a lot more)

** frequency, which is what really matters here, would be somewhat less than 10x faster because FD increases the amount of data per packet in addition to just frequency

I thought star topology usually refers to running the CAN wires from a central hub that usually results in wires close to or over the 12in limit. I‚Äôve usually considered there to be 3 wiring methods: daisy chain, star, and bus & stub. Bus & stub I‚Äôve usually described like how you drew star, and I believe is how it is described in the ISO standard.

CAN technically always uses ‚Äúbus & stub‚Äù wiring, just that most FRC components have the stub built into the circuitry of the component itself such that the wires/ connectors are technically part of the bus, allowing for a daisy chain.
